characters: ON THE HOLE BENEATH LUKE'S BUNK
LUKE AS GLOVE SMASHES INTO HIS FAC
ON LUKE WITH KOKO AND SOCIETY RED LATER
EXT. MESS HALL INSIDE YARD BEFORE DAWN, (NIGHT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NIGHT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its irritating head opens a glaring red eye: the red flag pops across the entire screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP of a pipe cutter attached to the meter neck, meta slivers curling out. From o.s. we HEAR -- LUCAS JACKSON  cheerfully humming and mumbling Auld Lang Syne and then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mister General, you son of a  bitch. Sir. Think you can put things  right with a piece of tin with a  ribbon hangin' on it? Gonna put you  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the meter head falls out of FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: METER, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: as it falls to the ground amidst a forest of meter stands and Luke's hand comes into the FRAME to pick it up and we SEE him in CLOSEUP for the first time. He is cheerful, dr wearing a faded GI Field jacket. A bottle opener hangs on silver chain around his neck. He addresses the next meter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Helen, honey. I lost my  head over you. Now its your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the beam of headlights crashes in, FLARING the  SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: PROWL CAR, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: sliding up to us, headlights glaring, red toplight revolv menacingly. TWO OFFICERS, black shapes, get out and start warily toward Luke.

dialogues.speaker: ON LUKE, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: illuminated by the headlights. He grins as the Officers  approach, lifts a bottle of beer, opens it and drinks,  smiling. On his smile, FREEZE FRAME. ON THE FRAME SUPER-I MAIN TITLE and as it FADES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It swings with a pendulum motion, its shining blade toppi a clump of grass and weeds; it swings on the backstroke,  lopping more grass, then moves a little away from CAMERA. FROM CAMERA RIGHT, a pair of feet move INTO the FRAME, th feet of the man swinging the yoyo. They are booted and  connected by chains, riveted around the ankles. The feet  move further INTO the FRAME and the SHOT WIDENS. We are o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and we see the work gang in uniforms (14 men) flailing aw with yoyos, short-handled scythes in the hot sun, guarded three men. Three of the workers wear chains (Gambler,  Dynamite, Sailor). The scene is bleached and hot; the men sweating and dirty in prison shirts and pants. The light  shifts during the following:

dialogues.speaker: RABBIT
dialogues.text: He is a trustee. He walks up INTO CAMERA and sets up sign

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: He is a giant, covered with sweat and dust. He starts to  pull off his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takin' it off here, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, take it off, Dragline!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pulling out watch, looking at the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flailing away, most of them naked to the waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sweating streams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wipin' it off here, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, wipe it off there, Koko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko takes out a limp handkerchief and mops his face.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLER, (A CHAINMAN)
dialogues.text: his yoyo flashing like a sword. He pauses, panting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinkin' it up here, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, drink it up, Gambler. Water  'em, Rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Gambler takes a drink from a tin cup, passed by Rabbit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: working away like a machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godfrey is the Walking Boss, silent, implacable symbol of ultimate judgement. He wears a black hat, globular mirror sunglasses -- the Man With No Eyes, impassive, emotionles He nods to Boss Shorty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, smoke it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In unison they chant:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Society is checking his yoyo edge with a file, covertly  watching a passing car. Blind Dick sneaks a look, then du

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You eyeballin' there, Society?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checkin' my yoyo, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: KOKO
dialogues.text: He sees something o.s. He speaks, as they all do outside, like a ventriloquist, not moving the lips, and in a stage whisper, to Dragline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drag... Drag... Newmeat Bus! We got  us Newmeat tonight!

dialogues.speaker: GAMBLER AND DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: They look up covertly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newmeat Bus, a prison vehicle, a panel truck with mes windows; and men in it, appears down the road approaching the gang. It slows as it passes them and the men covertly look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) A bunch. Must be halfa dozen Newmeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more than five. For a cold drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Bet! Babalugats, bet here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the idiot of the gang. He grins foolishly, making t bet official.

dialogues.speaker: NEWMEAT BUS
dialogues.text: as it passes, picking up speed, PAN INTO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking at the Newmeat Bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sunglasses FILL THE SCREEN, distorting the image of t bus as it moves away from us and the last TITLE ROLLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SCREEN is mostly black, but we see out through the me rear windows a desolate panorama of gnarled trees and gru landscape, bleak and hopeless. Now we HEAR outside the barking and baying of bloodhounds not like they're tracking, but just playing as the truck  turns and stops. The BUS GUARD and DRIVER get out. The ba of the truck is opened by the guard and through that rect of bright sunlight, the silhouettes of the Newmeat descen Luke last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scene: in a hollow is a long barracks, white-washed,  faded gray, one story high. At right is a mess hall and  laundry. A chain-link fence surrounds the whole compound. The corners of the fence are telephone poles with floodli on the tops. These burn all night. Back of the mess hall, again outside the fence, are several kennel runs in which bloodhounds are now ROARING. A wooden tower with a simple board roof stands at two corners of the compound where th guards sit when the prisoners are not locked in the barra A picnic table sits in a grassy area just outside and at side of the gate is a picket fence enclosing a scrubby la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the papers to the CAPTAIN, a small man with a ki face but a firm, set mouth who always carries a golf club In b.g. the bloodhounds are YOWLING:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogboy, get them dogs shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOGBOY, a trustee whose leather gloves are always stickin out of one back pocket, puts his hand to be licked by the dogs who quiet, friendly, like any pets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just smell newmeat is all, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain has been ignoring this, watching the prisoner looking at their records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Bosses (BOSS PAUL and BOSS HIGGINS) motion for the the other Newmeat (to be known as TRAMP, ALIBI, and TATTO stumble into each other and jostle Luke in their eagernes to obey orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You men git lined up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newmeat jostle into line. They are wearing State Issu gray pants and their own Free World shirts. All except Lu carry a paper bag or cigar box containing their wordly go All except Luke look apprehensive, worried. Luke stands w languid grace, neither insolent nor hostile, nor fearful. The Bus Guard hands Boss Paul a folder that contains reco as the Captain approaches from his porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they bring us today? Gibson.  A 507, Manslaughter. Good for a two  spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an accident. I've never been  in any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'all call the Captain, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to next man) Edgar Potter. A 302 and resisting  arrest. One year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was tryin' to keep outa the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git the wax out'n yore ears. You  call the Captain, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you call the rest of us Boss,  you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is gonna make us proud of  him, Mr. Hunnicutt. (moving on) Raymond Pratt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakin', enterin' and assault. Five  spot. Hmmm. Able-bodied seaman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That oughta come in handy here,  Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. (turning to Luke) Lucas Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maliciously destroyin' municipal  property while under the influence.  What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuttin' the heads off parkin' meters,  Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we ain't never had one of them.  Where'd you think that was gonna get  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you could say I wasn't  thinkin', Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at record) Says here you done real good in the  war: Silver Star, Bronze Star, couple  Purple Hearts. Sergeant! Little time  in stockades. Come out the same way  you went in: Buck Private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Captain. Just passin'  the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at him) Well, you got yourself some time  now. Two years. Hell, that ain't  much, we got coupla men here doin'  twenty spots. We got one who's got  all of it. We got all kinds and you  gonna fit in real good. Course in  case you git rabbit in your blood  and decide to take off fer home, you  git a bonus a some time and couple  leg chains to keep you slowed down a  little -- fer your own good. You'll  learn the rules. It's all up to you.  I can be a good guy or I can be one  mean son-of-a-bitch, it's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes have been wandering during this speech. He sees doleful, lovable bloodhound, nose at the mesh and winks a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He simply stares dolefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bare, unpainted wood. The windows are barred and covered  with chain link. The door from the barracks up to the com passes a small area enclosed by a woven metal strap cage. this usually sits the WICKER MAN, whom we generally see a heavy, short shape moving about his own business which is making an endless series of rings or jewelry by hammering coins with the back of a heavy spoon. The door to the barracks locks by the tongue of a strap i bar that is thrust through a hole in the wicker where the Wicker Man locks it by padlock. Thus he can always see th but they can't reach him. The single big room is filled w two and even three-tiered bunks. Bare bulbs hang from the ceiling. CARR, the floorwalker, a 240 pound behemoth, is indoctrin the Newmeat while they change into camp clothing: gray tw trousers, shirt and jacket, all numbered, which has been  piled on the table. Carr squeegees up and down, a restles man, and CAMERA in following him SHOWS us the room. At th same time, the Wicker Man is moving about the barracks,  tapping the floors and bunk posts with a broom handle for signs of tampering. Carr pays no attention to him, addres the Newmeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them clothes has got laundry numbers  on 'em. You remember your number and  always wear the ones that has your  number. Any man forgets his number  spends a night in the box. (passing out spoons) This yere spoon you keep with you  and any man loses his spoon spends a  night in the box. There is no playing  grabass or fighting in the building.  You got a grudge against another man  you can fight him Saturday afternoon.  Any man playing grabass or fighting  in the building spends a night in  the box. First bell is at five minutes  of eight when you will get in your  bunk and last bell is at eight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. now are heard the SOUNDS of trucks arriving and the  Wicker Man goes back to the wicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Any man not in his bunk at eight  will spend a night in the box. There  is no smoking in prone position in  bed. To smoke you must have both  legs over the side of your bunk.  Anyone caught smoking in prone  position will spend a night in the  box. You get two sheets. Every  Saturday you put the clean sheet on  the top, the top sheet on the bottom  and the bottom sheet you turn in to  the Laundry Boy. Any man who turns  in the wrong sheet spends a night in  the box. No one will sit on the bunks  with dirty pants on. Any man sitting  on a bunk with dirty pants will spend  a night in the box. Any man who don't  bring back his empty pop bottles  spends a night in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. now are the SOUNDS of men counting off, filling the with the apprehension of impending arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Any man loudtalking spends a night  in the box. You got questions you  come to me. (attentive now) I'm Carr, the floorwalker. I'm  responsible for order in here and  any man that don't keep order...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke mouths the next line with him. At the same time, we  HEAR the clanking of the Wicker Man's doors opening and t thudding of many steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...spends a night in the box. (to Luke, sincerely) I hope you ain't gonna be a hardcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Luke shrugs the chute bursts open and the Bull Gang ru in, men trying to get hands clean, urinate and get back o into the chowline. Sudden LOUD CHAOS. The Newmeat are sea on the bench, bewildered, except Luke who grins. Koko spi the Newmeat and is unhappy that there are only four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Koko) Four. You owe me a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing both aside) Get outa mah way you don't want a  wet pocket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing the Newmeat) Gentlemen, welcome to the Family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of you guys from Connecticut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, let's move it along!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the flow of bodies reverses and the men stampede for t chute, going out, adjusting clothing, etc. Dragline shove Loudmouth Steve along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fill your loudmouth with some beans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they are in the chute. The Newmeat still sit there. . the empty barracks, the SOUND of men disappearing across yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what are you doin' here? You  supposed to be eatin' them beans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newmeat stampede out the chute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the other men already have their food and are sit down with no jockeying for places: everybody knows. They shoveling it down as fast as they can, getting back up fo seconds. Luke and the other Newmeat get their plates and  while the others stand there, confused, Luke sits at the  first vacant spot and begins to eat industriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce to Dragline) Newmeat's a hog-gut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline looks up, goes back to his food. There is an off stage CRASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sitting on the floor, between his knees a mess of s on the floor and his plate upside down. He has made the  mistake of taking Dynamite's seat. DYNAMITE, the champion eater, has casually displaced him and is busy chowing. Do is serving; he is the only one to break the rule of silen in chowlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These pigs is rollin' in thar slops  now, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tramp makes terrified and ineffectual efforts to scoop th stew back onto his plate with his hand, wiping his hand o his uniform, etc., then trying to obliterate the stain on the floor with a foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are being shaken down before entering the barrack for the night. They sit and take off their shoes. They em their pockets into their caps. Carr inspects shoes, throw them inside door, frisks men who stand with backs turned, arms raised. Then Carr mutters a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the Wicker Cage toward door. As the men enter, st to pick up shoes, repeat their number to the Wicker Man, they go through the chute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are preparing for their hour of free time. Gamble has layed out the blanket for the poker game and is shuff cards. Koko and BLIND DICK have their seats, are arrangin their piles of change. Luke sits at the other end of the  table, past the blanket line. Dragline who has been talki to the Wicker Man now enters casually as we HEAR Dynamite change in hand, moving to the game berating Tramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time you stay outa my place! I  earned it. You try that agin an'  I'll bounce you all over the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know. I was hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't take another man's place,  boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't his fault. Nobody said  anything about seats. We --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tramp) You gotta mind your manners, you  actin' like a hillbilly tramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) Tramp! Beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tramp) You got your bullgang name, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly) Ain't no worse than some I been  called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Navy, we used to call guys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fasten your flap! All you Newmeats  gonna have to shape up fast and hard  on this gang. We got rules here an'  in order to learn them, you gotta  keep your ears open and your mouths  shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke snorts.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: looking up as if he has just heard a strange sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody say somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say nothin', Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whatta we got here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Lucas Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at mirror, back turned) Dragline gives out the names here.  You'll get yours when he figures you  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke) Maybe we oughta call you No-Ears.  You don't listen much, do you, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Ain't heard much worth listening to  yet. Just everybody handing out rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feeling of discomfort. Koko assesses Luke, who has rema at the poker table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newmeat looks like a poker player,  Drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't surprise me none. (to Luke) Wicker Man says you got a hundred- twenny and some change in the  Captain's safe and you got your five  dollars pocket money... That'll buy  you a whole fistfull of cards. You  in or out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke stares at him for a beat, then shrugs -- who needs i and walks over to his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you've got yourself a  redhot, Dragline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline just stares after Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dealing) Awright, let's play some poker. First  Jack is the Man... a trey, a duck, a  neighter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues to call cards as we PAN AWAY and DOWN the bu showing Alibi writing a letter, Loudmouth Steve reading a sex book, STUPID BLONDIE working a rattleskin wallet, SAI removing his pants through his chains, CHIEF rolling  cigarettes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow of the Wicker Man behind it rises and moves to the tire rim which he beats with a tire iron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First bell!

dialogues.speaker: POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: The men break it up, some head for the urinal.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He lies in his bunk staring directly into a flyspecked bu hanging from the ceiling about eighteen inches from his f It will be on all night. The tire iron SOUNDS again and m hurry for their bunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last bell. Last bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr moves down the aisle, counting lips moving. The barr is silent. Finishing the count, Carr goes to the Wicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty. Okay, Carr.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: staring up at bulb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittin' up here, Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacing along, his feet squeegeeing on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeeahp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the sleeping barracks he gets up and moves toward the  toilets...

dialogues.speaker: BABALUGATS
dialogues.text: He is crouched in a tortured position to pray, in the spa between his bunk and the one above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rolls over and goes to sleep. SOUND OVER: Carr squeege along, the CREAK of the bunks as men toss and turn, the W RUNNING in the toilets, the DOGS BARKING a little outside

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: He sits at the poker table. The sound has dropped now in depth of the night, the chink, chink of the Wicker man  stopped. Carr simply sits staring at his half-finished ga of solitaire, a card in his hand, his eyes seeing somethi far distant. He's breathing but he could be carved of sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All others sleeping. Carr at poker table. Suddenly the cl of the iron bar is HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First bell! First bell! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: ALIBI
dialogues.text: as, still asleep, he is unceremoniously dumped onto the f by Carr who goes right by. Pandemonium of rushing men all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr is barring the gate with his body. The door outside unlocked and opened. The gong SOUNDS. Carr opens the gate steps outside to the porch and the men begin counting out

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BARRACKS PORCH BEFORE DAWN, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: The voices continue to count off as the men run to locker and quickly line up outside the mess hall. Watching them is Boss Godfrey.

dialogues.speaker: GODFREY'S FACE
dialogues.text: impassive behind the sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MESS HALL INSIDE YARD BEFORE DAWN, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: The men pour out. There is a little dawnlight, but the  floodlights are still on. The Yard Man opens the gate and the men begin counting off again. Gambler is the last out the mess hall and gets a kick in the ass from Boss Paul t get him up with the others.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN'S PORCH BEFORE DAWN, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: He sits in his rocket watching. We hear the SOUND of the counting, clanging of chains.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK BEING LOADED, (DAWN)
dialogues.text: The men clamber inside. The Little Bull Gang truck leaves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caravan of the Little Bull Gang and Patch Squad trucks mo off down the road into the dawn light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: just as the gate is swung shut. We SEE Godfrey's face loo in, then all is dim and the truck begins to lurch away,  gunning fast, throwing the men, searching for their custo seats. Chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git outa my eyeballin' seat, you  Newmeat dummy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke stands, holding a strut in the roof and watching wit amusement as Tattoo is shoved away by Dragline, then Koko and then pushed from man to man as he tries to sit down b always finds a lap in the way. Bawdy laughter; it's a gam but earnest. As they settle Tattoo winds up on the floor grins, understands, finds a place beside Tramp. Across th way Alibi begins a serious conversation with Blind Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Where are we going now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Captain's birthday. They're  takin' us on a picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertainly smiling) I'm a salesman. I used to drive these  roads all the time. I never thought --  it was an accident, car skidded,  maybe I'd had a drink or two --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man! It's gonna be one hot muther  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bears gonna be walkin' the road today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tattoo) You ever seen a man bearcaught?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tattoo and Tramp look uncertain, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the salt goes outa his body and  the water follers the salt and the  brain shrivels up like a dried pea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to ingratiate) When I was in the Navy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Alibi) Convulsions, shivering. Very  unpleasant to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Alibi) Man's never the same. Makes him lose  his sex drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tramp) I'm lucky I got a broom. Work up  top. Real easy job. Man, it's gonna  be hot down in that ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We work down in the ditch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you never seen a chain gang,  in all your driving around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Koko) I ain't used to hard labor neither.  Done my best to avoid it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't crazy about it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Gonna be a hot one to learn on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko, why don't you let one of these  Newmeats take your broom for today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, no. I ain't goin' down in the  ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shore would appreciate it. I ain't  in much shape just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tramp and Tattoo) Perhaps if you offered Brother Koko  a small... (makes money gesture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't got much. A quarter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Koko) You was to sell your job, maybe this  Lucas War Hero would give you a price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you fifty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty cents? Sweet job like that  worth at least a buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck is a deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically to  Tramp, Tattoo) I've got this weak heart. Too much  drinking, I guess. As soon as they  find out about it, they'll probably  send me someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you even need dough in here, I'm  in big trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dragline) Where'd you get that about war hero?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh we got our sources... Tearing the  heads off... what was it... gumball  machines? What kind of thing is that  for a grown man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused by the put-on) Well, you know. Small town, not much  to do in the evenings. Mostly it was  settling up old scores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to do better than that  if you want to impress these men.  Some pretty hard numbers here.  Dragline's an ex-safe cracker, Koko's  a jewel thief. Blind Dick is a rapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke) Show you the clippings some time.  News-Dispatch called me "The Shiek  of Simmonsville." Five broads in  three days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course two of them were sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course some of them, like Stupid  Blondie, were just unlucky... he  fell off the fire escape... and one  or two don't really belong here at  all... (indicates Babalugats) ...or myself, who just made the small  error of misspelling a friend's  name... on a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Koko. You hear that? All this  time I been thinkin' Society just  come here for the sun and exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke who is smiling) Whatta you so happy about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just always did like truck rides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the trucks pull up and stop and the men pour out, pick up tools for the day's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards for the day are: Paul, Kean, Higgins and Godfr As the men move through the line for tools, Alibi approac Boss Paul:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss, I made an arrangement with  that man to take his broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving him along) Git your shovel and git to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand. We  made a deal ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (canes him on the leg) Git movin', I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in pain) But I made this arrangement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving him) Cut that backsass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alibi sees the light, accepts a shovel and walks off  resentfully to where the others are working, casting hurt angry looks at Koko and Society who ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUN COMES UP
dialogues.text: in Godfrey's glasses, and we SEE the gang begin their wor In VARIOUS CUTS, in each of which the sun leaps forward,  time passing inexorably...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rhythmically working away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to pretend to work, not doing it well and getting passing cut from Boss Paul's cane. Resentfully, he goes a it, sweating heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is working hard but badly, unused to the awkward tool, trying to master it. Society Red works up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're working too hard. You won't  last two hours. Watch the way the  Human Dragline does it.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: He is whipping away with apparently effortless ease but  accomplishing more than the others.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD
dialogues.text: An open red Continental with kit zips past, the driver  grinning at the Gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is suffering along, sweat pouring off him. The sun is  beginning to really beat down now. Dragline works a littl behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takin' it off here, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, take it off there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off his jacket and tosses it to the edge of the  road where Dogboy collects it. Tattoo decides to imitate, tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takin' it off here, Boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, take if off there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strips, revealing a tattoo of "Mother" lodged thornlik in his flesh and a great garland of flowers and a girl on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Hey, turn around! Let Koko see the  broad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: turning so Koko can see, grinning, stopping work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful! A real work of art!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low voice) Nice broad. Good set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly, flexing it) Had it done in Singapore. Bunch of  us drunk as coots --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hissing) Hey, Tattoo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not hearing) -- went down to see this old hag and  she had needles the size of that  cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Hey. Swing that yoyo or you gonna  get a taste of that cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tattoo realizes where he is and goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he seems to spin, his eyes closed, his arms limp, his  head lolling back, he stumbles, twists, careens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seeing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man bearcaught, boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blondie... Sleepy! Git him afore he  falls.

dialogues.speaker: STUPID BLONDIE AND SLEEPY
dialogues.text: They drop their tools and rush over as Tramp falls. Witho ceremony, they drag him over the rough ground to the truc where Boss Paul locks him in.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: He is watching Luke, who is very close to the same fate.  Although he has achieved some grace, it is apparent that  Luke is working too strenuously, too determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into his pocket and takes out a turnip watch,  looks to Godfrey, who nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, let's eat them beans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men break and head for the chow line.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He has dropped to the ground, examining a blister on his  hand. At Boss Kean's call, he looks up, ruefully resentfu and gets to his feet and slowly walks to the chow line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you. Bean time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing Luke, to  Gambler) Cold drink he don't make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet. Babalugats, bet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babalugats grins. Dragline has his chow, passes Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) You got to snag it, man. You got to  stop foolin' around and tear up them  weeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke stumbles past, not paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is later in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: ON STUPID BLONDIE
dialogues.text: He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caught short here, boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, Blondie. Take it behind  that tree.

dialogues.speaker: ON STUPID BLONDIE
dialogues.text: He drops his tool and gratefully trots off in the directi of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It is later. He is working hard, stops a minute as he HEA a crow cawing overhead. He looks up at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, TATTOO, KOKO, OTHERS
dialogues.text: looking up as Rabbitt goes to the truck and gets out a si action rifle which he brings to Godfrey, who puts in a bo and bullets from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Godfrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walking boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't he ever talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godfrey has raised the gun and now FIRES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is hit, explodes in a burst of feathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe he just said something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: working, Luke flailing away like an automaton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it is opened from the outside. Tramp sits up against t bench, still in rocky shape from his collapse. The others step over him as though he weren't there. Luke appears, l a sleepwalker. He grabs the side rails, gets one foot up tries to pull himself over the edge of the truck body. Bu the muscles are just used up. Boss Paul sees this and giv Luke a kick, timed so that it coincides with his jump. It gives him just the added momentum needed to send him over the edge of the body and sprawling along the floor. He's last one and as the guards lock them up, he grins up at  Dragline and Gambler from his prone position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dragline) You owe that fella a cold drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are not tired, they smoke and talk and laugh: it' been an easy day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot damn, Drag. Tomorrow's Saturday.  Another week almost made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopelessly) I got two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only two? Man, I already done eight.  Nothin' to it. Just make the days  and let the weeks and the years make  themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did three hitches in the Navy. It  ain't bad. After a while, you get  used to it and the time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko is looking out the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, oh man. Look at that. On  the bicycle. Lookit them shorts. I'm  dyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men rush to look out at the vision of freedom on the  bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowledgeably) She looks just like a lil girl I  useta know named Louise Merryweather.  Fine lil ol' girl, always partial to  home-made whiskey. Remember one time  down in the cellar, both of us knee- walkin' drunk and ah had this lil  pint and Louise wanted a poke of it.  So ah said: you wanna poke and I  wanna poke, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts his story. On the floor, Luke sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they are counting in through the gate, their hats with their personal possessions in them held out to be inspect their pockets turned out. A guard frisks them quickly but efficiently. The Captain stands nearby ignoring them, tes a golf swing. The men move to the mess hall, most of them the run. Luke moves painfully with exhaustion. Alibi seem quiet and cowed, lost in the crowd. They fall into a line the mess hall door. Dynamite, his spoon out, moves to the front of the line and Luke winds up somewhere near the re

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yardman) Awright, you, Gibson, step out. Boss  Paul says you wasn't happy with your  job. Done a lot of complainin'. Gone  give you a chance to think it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alibi looks around, fearfully steps out, peering up and d the line, wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get them clothes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alibi is led to the box. A light stands about it shining  down into it and it always burns when the box is ready to used or when there's someone inside. Now a nightshirt is  laid out on top of it. Alibi strips and puts on the pajam Boss Kean opens the heavy lid of the box and we see it is grilled with heavy chain link fencing and with strap iron bars. A chamber pot is put inside. Alibi stands in the bo looking back at them, then lies down out of sight. The li is slammed shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men watching this. The mess hall door opens and they  begin to file in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Wicker Man whales away at his tire rim outside the barracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, first bell! Let's hit them  bunks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are piling into bunks and the CAMERA FINDS Luke  heaving himself with a kind of rueful amusement up to the third tier bunk he sleeps in; he's exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plumb busted out. Looks like the  hard road finally got to Mister Lucas  War Hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeably) Back at it in the mornin'. Just need  a little nap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies back. Across him and in various perspectives are other participants in this conversation, speaking in the  ventriloquist's whisper while the stragglers get into the sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I never thought they'd put him  in the box on his first day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just supposed to be a joke.  There ain't no brooms. Whoever heard  of a chain gang using brooms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta tell you that I believed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should have known; it was a gag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't switch 'round jobs, anyway.  I figured he knew that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't expect him to learn  everything the first day. Hopefully  it's taught him a very valuable  lesson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you fixed it up so he's got  all night to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not our fault he's a square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course not. He ain't in the box 'cause  a the joke played on him. He's there  'cause he back sassed a Free Man.  They got their rules and we ain't  got nothing to do with that. Woulda  probably happened to him sooner or  later, to a complainer like him.  He's gotta learn the rules same as  anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, those poor old guards need all  the help they can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tryin' to say somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke rolls over and goes to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his back) You jus' keep flapping your mouth  and one of these times, you and me  gonna raise a little dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wicker Man begins hitting the tire rim again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, last bell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Forty-nine and one in the box, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-nine and one in the box. Right,  Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It slashes away like a pendulum, golden in the sun, TICKI away time, over roads that stretch to infinity -- a SHOT  that will always tell us that the men are building time.  SHOT WIDENS. The gang is laboring, filling in washouts by the roadside. The bosses are Paul, Kean, Higgins, and, al Godfrey, the Walking Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is tanned and hardened now, and has mastered the work  rhythm. SHOT WIDENS to show Dragline near him, checking h shovel for nicks but really eyeballing a passing car. In ditch, Luke expertly scoops up a shovel full of sand and, levering the handle on his knee, flips the sand through t air so it hits spang in the pan of Dragline's shovel whil Dragline is still eyeballing. It knocks him off balance a by the time he has caught up, Luke is already catching hi with another shovel full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down, man. They ain't passing  out medals for slinging dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you knew, boy... they  sentenced me by the mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline grins at this insouciance, sneaks a look down th road. He digs into his pocket and hauls out a pair of sal sunglasses, which he holds up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puttin' 'em on here, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, put 'em on, Drag!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Dragline hooks on the glasses. Luke, Tattoo and Tramp working around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tramp) Lookit that. Some Hollywood movie  star jus' joined up with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tramp smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Koko) Man, this here Newmeat parking meter  bandit thing what calls itself Luke  don't know nuthin' 'bout nuthin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tramp) But damn if he don't look like a fat  old Dragline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coulda fooled me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tattoo) These is my eyeballin' glasses. Now  I'm gonna play peek-a-boo and ol'  Godfrey ain't gonna know if I'm  eyeballin' or tootin' the piccolo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't nuthing compared to what  we used to do in San Pedro. There  was this ensign...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has been sniffing  the air) Ah believe I smell me a blonde-haired  lady.

dialogues.speaker: BULL GANG
dialogues.text: They all look up covertly and, sure enough, in the second car slowed down by Rabbit's sign, is a lush BLONDE in a s dress that is hiked up high on the thighs and cut low ove the bosom. She cringes under their gaze and starts the to going up on the car as though to hide from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, see her legs. She's tanned all  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice broad. Nice set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks just like Mrs. Patricia  Handy, a married woman... I useta  fool with. Man, I kin sniff blondes  from a hunnert yards and redheads  from a mile and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tattoo) Drag's been chain-ganging so long  he's got a nose like a bloodhound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's been chain-ganging too  long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long enough to see redhots come and  redhots go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car begins to move away. They sigh. The work begins a

dialogues.speaker: GANG
dialogues.text: Time has passed; they are further down the road. A small  blue coupe kicks up dust as it jitters down the road and  stops across the highway before a small home. A blonde, m twenties, gets out, and heads covertly look up.

dialogues.speaker: THE BULL GANG
dialogues.text: The woman is too much for them, too close, too blonde, to lush. They stop as one and watch as she disappears into t house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing their odd behavior, he turns to see what's happeni but the woman is gone; when he turns back, the men's head are back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, did you see her? Did you  see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got eyes, don't I? How my not gonna  see something like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice broad. Good set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you tell? You could hardly  see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads pop up again as the blonde comes out of the house, dressed in a short house dress, carrying a radio, a pail a sponge. She is clearly buxom. She goes to the outside  faucet, fills the bucket and drags the attached hose towa the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, you loudmouth jerk!

dialogues.speaker: THE BLONDE
dialogues.text: She begins to hose the dusty car, splashing herself, maki the cotton dress cling to her body, tossing her hair, eve movement and gesture erotic and provocative.

dialogues.speaker: THE MEN
dialogues.text: Their work is completely disorganized as they attempt to  shovel while watching. Their voices overlap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man Oh Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is one mean lady. Bet her husband  spends one day a week shooting  milkmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit her bounce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh lean over here, lady. Lean this  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind being that hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More... a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so big!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now lean down... a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit that little honeypot. Lookit  those legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh man, I ain't never been so thirsty  in my life.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLONDE
dialogues.text: She begins to rub the windshield erotically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh rub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rub!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rub-a-dub-dub. Rub-a-dub-dub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dyin'. I'm dyin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, she's got paint on her toenails!  Oh Lord, whatever I done, don't strike  me blind for 'nother couple minutes.  Oh you Lucille!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucille? Where do you get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whirling) That'sa Lucille, you mullet head!  Any girl so innocent and built like  that gotta be named Lucille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Innocent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't even know what she's doin!.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows exactly what she's doin.  She's drivin' you crazy and lovin'  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth 'bout my Lucille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Lucille? Man, you better put  them glasses back on and take a look  at yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glaring) Boy. You jus' asking to be handled!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Godfrey moves across the scene, blocking their view,  staring at them, FILLING THE SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trashing bodies and heads in the steam. Feeling of tensio irritation, except for Babalugats, who is SINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babalugats, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him alone. He's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because he's a damn moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now why don't you just shut up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are in their bunks, sullen, quiet as the tire iro SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, last bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr paces, counting. Beds SQUEAK as men turn restlessly, unable to get comfortable. At the far end of the barracks slow-turning fan CREAKS gratingly. It will continue to do throughout the scene, adding irritation to Carr's SQUEEGE steps and the regular SQUEAKING of bedsprings.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: restless, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty, right, Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, it's so hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettin' up, Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Carr paces, SQUEEGEEING. The fan CREAKS. Springs SQUEA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeahhpp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gambler gets up, chains JANGLING.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: uncomfortable, tense, shifting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giddyap, Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeahhpp.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: Tramp turns, irritated, as Carr SQUEEGEES by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you sleep with that damn  squeaking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr pacing. SQUEEGEEING, the fan CREAKING, springs SQUEA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettin' up, Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeahhp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dynamite gets up, chains JANGLING.

dialogues.speaker: ON FAN
dialogues.text: It is turning slowly, CREAKING, CREAKING, CREAKING. And n on the SOUNDTRACK we HEAR low at first, but steadily buil the tinny SOUND of the Blonde Girl's radio.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: tense, annoyed, frustrated as the SOUND of the RADIO GROW joining the CREAKING, SQUEAKING and SQUEEGEEING.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: as Carr passes by. He speaks in a low whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, that lil Lucille was a lot of  lil girl.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: some turning away, not wanting to be reminded, some stari ahead unhappily, thinking the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see how she was jus' poppin'  outa the top of that dress.

dialogues.speaker: KOKO
dialogues.text: irritated, anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on, Drag.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: not paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And down below, that thing didn't  reach no higher than... (chuckles) She liable to catch cold... runnin'  around like that.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: irritated by Dragline's voice and the SQUEEGEEING and the SQUEAKING and CREAKING and the RADIO SOUND, tinny and gra growing in volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And that thing was so tight 'cross  her bottom... made me wanna just  reach out my hands and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, man.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: suddenly angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta you mean, forget it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop beatin', man. You ain't doin'  nobody no good.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: his face corroding in fury as the RADIO SOUND and the  CREAKING, SQUEAKING and SQUEEGEEING are at an unbearable  peak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with slow menace) Boy, you better get some sleep and  save your strength. 'Cause you're  gonna need it.

dialogues.speaker: FAN CLOSE
dialogues.text: As the SOUNDS threaten to burst our ears with their high- pitched tension, the CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY into the hub of fan and our nerves scream for relief.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE AS GLOVE SMASHES INTO HIS FAC
dialogues.text: (DAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and Luke falls back into the dirt. He's hurt, startled, b grins. We HEAR a CHEER from the men O.S., as he gets up. is stripped to the waist, wears huge 16 oz. boxing gloves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: showing Dragline similarly dressed. They are squared off the yard, surrounded by YELLING men who want blood. It is release from the sexual tension built up by the night bef The guards stand in the guard boxes, watching. The Captai sits up on his porch, so he can see without being too obv Luke gets up and manages a lunging right across to Dragli Adam's apple. Dragline is momentarily staggered but count with a terrible clubbing blow that mashes Luke's gloves i his face, knocking him to the ground. Time is called for round.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE AND OTHERS BEHIND HIM
dialogues.text: as he gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just stay there? He's  only gonna knock you down agin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your fault. He's just too  big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him hit you in the nose, get  some blood flowing. Maybe they'll  stop it before he kills you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head,  grinning) I don't want to frighten him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second round is called and Luke advances toward Dragl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: circling. Luke has to get in his shot before Dragline get too close and clubs him again. He feints a punch that mov Dragline off-balance and winds up for a big one, but Drag smashes him backhand. Luke hits the dirt, the men SCREAM YELL. Wiping some blood from his mouth, Luke rises again. is dizzy. Dragline smacks him down again.

dialogues.speaker: THE MEN
dialogues.text: SHOUTING, SHRIEKING, they have blood in their eyes, relea their tensions.

dialogues.speaker: THE VARIOUS REACTIONS
dialogues.text: as the fight continues. The Captain on his porch rocks an spits dry little spouts of wind, Godfrey, impassive, wait in his guard house. The YELLING gradually subsides as Dra continues to smash Luke, who keeps getting up.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: Without relish, he pokes Luke down again. Now there is no cheering, no yelling, just silence.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: as he gets up and walks down to the wire where he can see what is happening. The silence disturbs him.

dialogues.speaker: ON LUKE
dialogues.text: He rises, grinning and winds up to throw another punch. B the act of lifting his giant glove is a Herculean task.  Seconds go by in which he tries to raise the glove high e to launch a punch.

dialogues.speaker: ON DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: waiting, gloves at waist level, poised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Ommana pop you one easy. Stay down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pops Luke who reels, goes down on a knee and then slow rises, rises. Dragline is honestly agonized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna kill you, you go on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you're gonna have to do.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: concerned.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS GODFREY
dialogues.text: impassive.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: He raises his fists. But Luke is up again. Dragline reali he'll have to kill him to beat him. After a long moment,  Dragline drops his hands to his sides, looks back toward  Godfrey and the captain and then starts walking to the  barracks, fast.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He looks after him and reaches up to wipe the blood away, still grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poker game. Five card stud. Playing are Gambler, Koko Dynamite, Blind Dick and Luke, bandaged. The mood of the  barracks is quieter than usual. The men are still assessi the fight, uncertain as to who now is their leader, looki toward Dragline for an indication. Not playing, Dragline  lies on his bunk behind Koko, sullenly reading a sex book Gambler deals the third cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana paira ninas. Koko's the brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dynamite is already out. Blind Dick now folds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kick a buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considers, then chips) I'm in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace calls. Here we go. (deals Luke) King-five gets a tray for no help. (deals Koko) Paira ninas gets a Jack. (deals himself) Ana man with the ace gets... slop in  the face... Ninas up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regarding Luke) Cuter again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expressionless) Kick a buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko is worried. He looks at his hole card, considers, lo silence. Dragline looks over from his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Koko) Whatcha got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pair'a nines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kin see that, brick head. I mean  your hole card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko hands it over his shoulder to Dragline, who now sits to consider the whole situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Uh-huh. And he ain't got nothing  showing. Raise his head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been betting his head from the  gun. Gotta have kings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then you just call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chipping) I call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studies Luke's cards) I gotta believe. Out! (folds) Now they're rollin'. (deals Luke) King-five-four gets an eight. (deals Koko) Pair'a nines with a Jack gets a four.  Ninas still up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Cuter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (automatically) Kick a buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up to Dragline for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kick him back a buck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko looks uncertain, but listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back a buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (automatically) Kick a buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko looks up to Dragline: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at me, mullet-head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko looks to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you play like a kokonut. You  got to call him at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he's got a paira kings. He  don't have to stick 'em in my ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta have kings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure he's got kings but you still  gotta call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko looks back to Dragline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man's got a paira kings, get your  tail out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko folds. Luke reaches for the pot at the same time tha Dragline reaches for Luke's cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuthin'! A handfull of nuthin'! (cuffs Koko) You stupid mullet-head. He beat you  with nuthin'! Just like today when  he kept coming back at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Nuthin' can be a pretty cool hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool Hand Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So saying, Dragline saves face and the baton of leadershi is passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: swinging away the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING THROUGH cage truck, as it moves swiftly along, t landscape a blur of shadows and racing phone poles, etc., the men shadows slouched on their benches inside.

dialogues.speaker: BEARCAUGHT AVENUE
dialogues.text: This is a country road running over rolling moors, land o to the sky and sun, the roads reaching out to infinity. T cage truck rolls to the end of the road and stops. Stretc out on either side of the road, every five feet is a pyra of freshly dumped sand.

dialogues.speaker: REAR OF TRUCK
dialogues.text: as the bull gang gets down, looks at the sand, are given  shovels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, man! Not on this hot muther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the bears gonna be walking today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) What's the deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tar truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At these bleak words, over the last rise comes a filthy  blackened tank truck with a fire in its belly and an arra of pipes and valves at its rear, like a hellish beetle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tattoo, Tramp,  Alibi) You think you've been working hard.  This muther'll break your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a big day for the guards.  They get to remind us who's boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't forgot.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MEN
dialogues.text: as the truck driver makes adjustments in the heater, flam etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, every second man, git to  the other side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline, Dynamite, Gambler, Tattoo, Loudmouth Steve, Ali Sleepy, Stupid Blondie and Chief cross over, leaving Luke Koko, Society Red, Tramp, Babalugats, Blind Dick, Mechani and Sailor. The tar truck begins to move slowly down the  road, spreading a black, hot, acrid wake behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; with  undisguised malice) Captain heard this gang been doin'  so good, gave us this special job.  We got three miles of tarrin' to  cover today. Let's roll it!

dialogues.speaker: THE MEN
dialogues.text: They begin to work, digging a shovel-full of sand, fannin it out over the hot tar, moving up to the next pile. Luke and Dragline in the lead of their respective groups. The  guards move up along the ridges behind the men, urging th to move faster, caning the slow workers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's git with it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll it, heah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is at the rear of the columns, walking down the center the road. With his stick he points to spots where the tar has not been covered and the nearest man flicks a spray o sand over it.

dialogues.speaker: ON LUKE WITH KOKO AND SOCIETY RED LATER
dialogues.text: They are working steadily but it is hot, hard, back-break labor. Koko stops for a moment to rub his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh man. I'm gonna twist my arm off  if this heat don't kill me first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Paul canes him across the legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll it!

dialogues.speaker: ON DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: sweating and suffering across the road, just keeping up w Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy. Take it easy. You're  making me look bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man wants speed, let's give it  to him. Ram it in and break it off.  Go hard. Shag it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline begins to work harder, digging and fanning, keep pace with Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panting) Whatta we racin' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man wants speed, let's give it to  him. Use that shovel like you use  your spoon. Shag it, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dynamite understands and throws himself into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: up to their waists in smoke and dust, splattered with tar working like devils as the word passes down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Society Red) Go hard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tattoo) Ram it in and break it off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sleepy) Roll it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shag it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all working like hell.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS PAUL
dialogues.text: He looks confused, concerned by this sudden manic activit

dialogues.speaker: BOSS GODFREY
dialogues.text: forced to walk faster to keep up, finding no unsanded spo for his sorcerer's wand.

dialogues.speaker: ON LUKE, DRAGLINE, OTHERS
dialogues.text: enjoying the guard's confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke) They don't know iff'n to smile, spit  or swallow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't never seen a bull gang  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work those shovels instead of your  mouths.

dialogues.speaker: WORKING ON BEARCAUGHT AVENUE
dialogues.text: Essentially a MONTAGE, a wild insane ballet of labor as l by Luke and Dragline, the bull gang throws itself into th madness, muttering Luke's words of inspiration to each ot and loving the guards' confusion. (SONG ON SOUND TRACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go hard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ram it in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break it off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shag it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke grins and works. The guards are tense and uneasy and walk the road backward, not daring to turn their backs on these madmen. Rabbit runs around with his water bucket bu the men don't drink, just upturn the water over their fac and keep going.

dialogues.speaker: ON BOSS PAUL
dialogues.text: confused, angry, has not been able to cane anyone in an h As Rabbit rushes by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbit! What the hell's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knows but isn't saying) I don't know, Boss. They must be  bearcaught. All of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes off, as caught up in the esprit as the others.

dialogues.speaker: WORKING AGAIN
dialogues.text: More of the madness but now even faster, sweatier, wilder The men are bearcaught by their sudden power to confound guards. ALL SHOTS FAVORING Luke, splattered with tar, wor right behind the truck.

dialogues.speaker: ON GODFREY
dialogues.text: Replacing his stick with a rifle, as tense and uncertain the other bosses, staring at Luke with blank, hating eyes

dialogues.speaker: ON LUKE
dialogues.text: as he looks up just as the tar truck turns off the road w has ended, crossed by a small highway. They have finished Luke stands straight, looking out across the highway to t rolling green beyond. Dragline works up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd the road go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. That's the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's still daylight left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking the sun) 'Bout two hours left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke has been looking at the guards who have grouped in  conference around Boss Paul who has his watch out. They l concerned, gesticulating toward Luke and the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others understand. They have beaten the Free Men by  working harder. They all collapse on the ground, rolling  about, dazed, tired but happy as hell, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Luke, you wild beautiful thing!  You crazy handful of nuthin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday afternoon scene. The chain men are dancing, jingli Three RADIOS BLARE in different corners; a hell-fire prea where Deacon and Society Red sit working a letter; romant ballads (Near You, Heart Aches by Ted Weeks, etc.) for th men reading fuck books; rhythm and blues, country music f a couple of wrestlers, banging into bunks until one depan the other and runs off. CAMERA FOLLOWS THIS ACTION SHOWIN the scene. Other men rolling cigarettes, Dynamite still o his rattlesnake wallet, Koko cutting hair, using a board  over an ash can for a barber's chair. Everyone is barefoo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visitor for Luke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke sits up from his bunk, staring at the Wicker, unmovi amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve. Your mother's here!

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: as he gets up. Behind him Loudmouth Steve gets up, tossin down his sex book resentfully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez! She never lets me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You oughta be glad you got somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve tosses him a finger as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife hasn't been here for a month.  She must be sick again. She's had  this condition of the liver for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alibi, can't you never say nothin'  without explainin' it? Carr says you  even explain when you get up at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the picnic table set up for visitors. In far b.g., we Luke come out of the door and start across the yard towar the gate, where he is shaken down and permitted to exit,  moving down to the table. A few feet from the end of the  table, Boss Godfrey sits in a kitchen chair, his hands  discreetly crossed over the pistol in his lap. His mirror eyes play over the scene. Loudmouth Steve, his MOTHER -- desperately fortyish blonde -- and a couple of other pris and visitors occupy the background. Parked next to the ta is a truck. In the bed lies Luke's mother, ARLETTA. She i propped up on pillows and wedged in for traveling. The whole back is set up as for a chronic invalid, everyt within reach, etc. She smokes incessantly. Nearby, Luke's BROTHER and his nephew, JOHN-BOY, a kid of twelve, enormo impressed with the sights and the guns and dogs, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comin' out here, Boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by the gate) Yeah. Come on out, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few feet outside the gate, Jackson reaches for the boy, pats him on the head. Shakes hands in passing with his  brother, who is unmistakably a farmer, and stands in the  doorway looking at his mother. She lies on her side crani to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, she sent along your things  with a note, and John here, he wrote  to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well. (to Godfrey) Gettin' up here, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godfrey just looks at him, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Arletta, I got to stand down  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I allus hoped to see you well fixed  and have me a crop of grandkids to  kiss and fuss around with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like to oblige you, Arletta, but  right off I don't know where to put  my hands on 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wisht people was like  dogs, Luke. Comes a time, a day like,  when the bitch just don't recognize  her pups no more, so she don't have  no hopes nor love to bring her pain.  She just don't give a damn. They let  you smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smokin' it up here, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Godfrey nods. He lights cigarettes for her and for  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, Arletta, you done your  best. What I done with myself is my  problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it hain't, Luke. You ain't alone.  Ever whar you go, I'm with you, and  so's John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never thought that's a heavy  load?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We allus thought you was strong enough  to carry it. Was we wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke gives her the cigarette, and smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But things ain't always like  they seem, Arletta. You know that. A  man's gotta go his own way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know, I just wash my  hands of it, I guess I just got to  love you and let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She catches his hand as he puts the cigarette between her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call it abuildin' time, Arletta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't askin' what you'll do after  you get out, because I'm gonna be  dead and it don't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother's disappointment in him brings Jackson a real  twinge of pain here. He tries to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never wanted to live forever  anyways, did you? It wasn't such a  hell of a life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I had me some high old times.  Yore old man, Luke, wasn't much for  stickin' around, but damn it he made  me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, would of been nice to of knowed  him, the way you talk about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's looking at him and begins to laugh, losing control coughing to the point it alarms John and Jackson and they have to help her. She pays no attention to the cough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd... He'd of... broke you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quiets after the fit and lies back, tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think life is some kind of ocean  voyage and you start out with buntin'  and hollerin' and high hopes, but  the damn ship goes down before you  ever reach the other side. Luke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What went wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. Ever'thing's cool's can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tried to live always just as free  and aboveboard as you been, and well,  they ain't that much elbow room.
