dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arletta is looking hard into his eyes as he speaks. She  reaches out to him again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You allus had good jobs, and that  girl in Kentucky I taken a shine to  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took off with that convertible  feller...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why not? Idee of marryin' got  you all choked up, trying to pretend  you was respectable you was borin'  the hell out of all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning at her) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leavin' the place to John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good: he earned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' to do with it. I ain't never  give John the kind of feelin' I give  you, so I'm payin' him off now. Don't  feel you got to say anything. Way it  is, sometimes, you just have a feelin'  for a child or you don't, and with  John I just didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go, Arletta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering) Laugh it up, kid. You'll make out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kneads his hand and subsides onto her bed. Luke turns away from her to face John, who has stood by. Godfrey is his feet. The other men are getting up and saying goodbye visitors, picking up their packages, etc., and among them a chain man, his chains dragging, holding them up with a  string. The kid stands by John looking at the chains clin past...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you have chains?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke looks up at John, Sr. with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Luke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John-Boy looks to you. You're a hero.  He's braggin' on you all over the  county.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must've really flung a binge  this time. You really hit that cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not liking the smug  pride in John) Much as I'd like to oblige you, John,  I didn't hit the cop. (beat) She's in pretty bad pain, ain't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Fulla dope, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it with her all the time. Let  her have all she wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They understand each other. Luke chucks John-Boy under th chin, then stops, looks at John, kneels beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to admire them chains,  John-Boy. They ain't medals. You get  them put on for makin' mistakes. (beat) And if you make a really bad mistake,  then you got to deal with the Man...  and he is one tough old boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godfrey stares at them, his glasses mirroring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, Arletta. Take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John holds Luke for a beat and reaches into the truck and pulls out a battered banjo which he gives Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's nothin' for you to come  back for.

dialogues.speaker: ARLETTA'S TRUCK
dialogues.text: LEAVING down the road, kicking up dust. Barracks in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cutting away at the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke sits on his bunk plunking aimlessly at the BANJO. Th barracks are quiet, an air of [...]. Suddenly there is an unidentifiable SOUND, low, but all the heads in the barra look up, waiting, silently. It has begun to rain, the big drops DRUMMING on the roof. It begins to fall heavily. Th are moving slams around the building as outside the guard SLAM the storm shutters. It is hot, oppressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they have to close those  things, or we'd drown. But it's really  suffocating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about drownin', I did some  trainin' on a submarine once. Boy,  when you're under there you really  feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, man. It's too hot to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is stifling, desultory. Out of boredom, Dragline  turns to Dynamite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see mah skinny lid boy at chow  tonight. He was matching you plate  for plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't feelin' good. Think I got a  ulcer or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had a spoon like yours, he'd make  you look like a possum [...] on a  tree bark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Society Red is lying on his bunk looking at the bottom of the bunk above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline sits up and looks at him aggressively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Clarence? You  callin' me a liar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a liar. You just have a common --  and likable -- tendency toward  exaggeration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) He's the champeen hog-gut of this  camp. Hell, I seen him eat ten  choc'lat bars and seven cold drinks  in fifteen minutes. He kin eat busted  bottles and rusty nails, any damn  thing. If you'd so kindly oblige as  to let me cut off your yankee head,  he'd even eat that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can eat fifty eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to look at him as though surprised to find him  there. Before Dragline can think he says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody kin eat fifty eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dragline) You just said he could eat anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully, to Luke) You ever eat fifty eggs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody ever ate fifty eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet! Bet! Babalugats!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mah boy say he kin eat fifty eggs,  he'll eat fifty eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but in how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I believe I'll have to take  part of that wager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, twenty bucks. Anything! The  Syndicate'll cover any money you  got. Koko, get paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline... fifty eggs got to weigh  a good six pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expertly) Man's gut can't hold that. They'll  swell up and bust him open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getcha money, up. Gambler! Dynamite!  Everybody. Kokonut Head here is taking  the money. Loudmouth -- get it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The initial boredom of the scene is dispelled -- a purpos has been created to lead them through the endless buildin of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's he gonna eat 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) Boiled for fifteen minutes. Then  peeled. I eat all fifty in one hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men are all around Dragline and Koko now with money and  wagers. Koko is frantically scribbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko, write down their names, don't  just make marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One rule! No throwing up. He throws  up, you forfeit everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever see mah boy throw up? Shut  your mouth and put up your money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koko is on the floor now with Babalugats beside him, asso papers, handing out betting receipts. Dragline turns to L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you have to say fifty? Why not  thirty-five or thirty-nine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty's a nice round number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, Luke. What's the matter with  you? what's the matter with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winking) Nothin' to worry about. We got a  deadlock on that mullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke and Dragline jog around the yard like roadwork for a boxer and trainer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do? Stole and tole lies.  I loved mah neighbor and his wife,  but what did I do to deserve this  lunatic to come in mah happy home  and beat me outa hard earned bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) We got it locked in the sock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. But what we gotta do  first is stretch that l'il ol' belly  of yours -- git it all strained out,  in fightin' shape, like a barrage  balloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ol' sack of guts. I had a belly  like yours, we wouldn't have nothin'  to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considers paunch) 'Atsa sign I got me an affectionate  nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like an elephant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Us elephants may be a lil slow, like  in makin' love, but you give us a  coupla three days to really get with  it an' man -- stand back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke grins.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE IN THE CHOWLINE
dialogues.text: taking enormous helpings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit this hot gut, Boss. Here's a  man gone bust the State feedin' his  face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wisht I could eat like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing about bad food, you got to eat  a lot of it.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He sits in a yoga position, rippling his stomach muscles  miraculously. Koko and Gambler pop INTO THE SHOT to watch with amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke refuses food. He moves to his place, sits before his empty plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Dragline stops in front of the Wicker Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss! Man needs a brown bomber and a  dose of salts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instant UPROAR of protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rules Committee! Rules Committee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody said nothin' about that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as dopin' a race horse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't sound right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You jes' watch us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair's fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a right to start with a clear  gut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man can't eat that much no matter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just change the rules any  way you want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of this is overlapping: Dragline walks through them  carrying the pile and cup of salts passed out from the Wi ignoring it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JABO, the cook, is lowering the sacks of eggs into huge p of boiling water. Carr stands by with a watch, timing. Ou the open door are Dragline, Dynamite and Gambler watching tensely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy now, Jabo. Them is eggs,  not them cathead biscuits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what eggs look like. I ain't  seen any around here for three years,  but I remember.

dialogues.speaker: BARRACKS DOOR, (DAY)
dialogues.text: as a file of men carry the still-steaming eggs in their h from the yard into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adding on a scrap of  paper) I've got it figured. If he eats an  egg a minute, he's got 10 minutes  left to swaller them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got sent five bucks from the  rodeo company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bull I fell off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the line of men reach the poker table and begin stacki up the eggs. The Rules Committee sits around the table le one side for Luke. It's all set up with towels, etc. They are counting eggs carefully, piling them in pyramids. Dra picks up an egg and cracks it smartly on the table. Again uproar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright! Stand back, you pedestrians,  this ain't no automobile accident!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're peeling his eggs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Mister Alibi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peels the eggs himself. That's  understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You jus' may be great at hangin'  paper around the big cities, but us  country boys is not entirely  brainless. When it comes to the law,  nothin' is understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who made what law about peeling his  eggs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm his trainer, I'm the syndicate  what's coverin' all bets, and I'm  his official egg peeler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait till the hour starts, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The champion enters and the talk dies. He's naked from th waist. He does some side-straddle hops and deep-knee bend His stomach is markedly concave. He, drying himself from shower, walks to the fragment of mirror on the wall and c his hair, studies his image a second and, at last ready,  moves to the table and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ingeniously) What's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline jumps up and gives a second's rubdown to Luke's  shoulders. There is a flurry of last minute betting, and  then silence. Everybody gathered around. Luke shuffles hi feet, twitches his toes. One egg from the pile is peeled in front of him. Carr waits, his eyes on his wrist watch, his other hand up in the air, and all eyes rest on that h All eyes drop as the hand drops. Dragline grabs eggs and  peels them, his fingers flickering, the shells flying. Lu picks up the peeled egg and eats it in a gulp.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He's eating very fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping a written  tab) One, two, three... (continues counting,  throughout)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna lose a finger eating eggs  like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline reaches over and pops an egg into Luke's mouth, pinkie extended, like tossing a tidbit into the mouth of  some animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others stand around, motionless. Dragline cracks and  peels and Luke eats in a regular musical rhythm inexorabl and horrible as it is sustained. Red is checking and coun off eggs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...twenty-four. Twenty-five, twenty- six...

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: His face bears an expression of ineffable absent pleasure though eggs reminded him of something a long way away.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: looking at him, neutral...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down a little.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Some chew fingernails, some stare, some mouth open, some  stand with unlighted cigarettes in their mouths, staring. Some have eyes shut, their lips silently counting with Re

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...thirty, thirty-one, thirty-two.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He stops and stands up, stretching. His stomach bulges as though he were pregnant. Slowly he walks across the barra toward the water faucet. Dragline stands looking after hi alarmed. Luke slowly bends over and washes his mouth out, not taking a drink. He stands, turns, walks up and down,  does some exercises. Silence, no one else moves. He walks back, looks at the eggs, making an expression of distaste He turns away and does some more exercises. Gambler moves over very close to him. Luke is going up and down, up and down doing knee bends. Gambler tries to look into his eye examine his stomach, listen to his wind. Luke sticks out tongue obligingly for a check. Gambler stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen to go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a flurry of last-minute betting led by Onionhead examination. Koko, Babalugats beside him, are the tellers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had it. I'm throwin' in my last  tenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleepy appears, as does Tramp, to make beta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expertly) Man's gut can't hold more'n that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you gonna come crawlin' around  beggin' for a cold drink, Drag. Your  boy is done for!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mechanic has been studying Luke as if he were an ailing  carburetor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Dragline) If I give you a dollar and he don't  eat all fifty eggs, I get two dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mechanic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline puts his arm around Mechanic's shoulders  affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sweet old boy and I don't  like to see you pick up no bad habits.  Better use that dollar to buy yourself  a new spark plug or something. But  as long as you done took a stand,  why don't you put some money where  your mouth is? Not no measly buck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I got is three-seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bet! Koko! I gone this far,  I'm backin' mah boy all the way!  Come on, who's next? Where are the  big money men, I want to hear from  some high rollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you've got it all, Dragline.  Every nickel in camp is riding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline turns to Luke and grins. Luke instantly appears recover and walks casually back to the table. It should b clear this last was a little put-on between him and Dragl to milk the last money into bets. Luke sits and begins ea

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: cool, confident, but as the egg is crushed in his mouth t first real gagging feeling of total surfeit hits him. His jaw closes and freezes. His eyes grow desperate and swive toward Dragline, though he doesn't dare move his head les he give way to nausea.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: reacts.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: with a herculean effort, he swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline swallows with relief. Gambler moves and looks ab a man feeling victory within his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr? What's the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-four minutes to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke swallows another egg; sweat bursts out on his forehe Dragline signals to a second, Koko, to sit in for him and peel eggs. He moves to Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Dragline stands behind him, massaging his shoulders an neck, tenderly... Luke doggedly eats eggs, one by one. Re counts off under...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-nine... forty... forty-one...  forty-two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, boy, come on, darlin'. You  kin do her. Just let that ol' belly  sag and enjoy itself. Stay loose,  buddy. Eight more, between you and  everlasting glory. Little ol' eggs,  pigeon eggs, that's all, fish eggs  practically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke almost throws up, and Dragline signals Koko to hold  up... he gets Luke of his feet and begins walking him up down the barracks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr? Time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six minutes to go, Dragline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into Luke's ear) Just shakin' it down, that's all,  settlin' them eggs down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits him down, takes an egg from Koko and puts it to L lips, pursing his lips in a kiss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Baby... don't be that way.  Open your little ol' gator mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke opens his mouth, in goes the egg, he chews, chews,  swallows. Another egg...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-four...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes to time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right now: get mad at them eggs.  Eat it there boy! Bite it! Gnaw on  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute, thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another egg goes. Luke closes his eyes and motions to  Dragline; just stuff 'em in any old how!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, that's how to do it, chew,  chew, chew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eggs peeled, Koko is up and dancing wildly, and a cou of men, even though they've got nothing but everything to lose, are intoxicated beyond power to restrain themselves and are yelling and jumping up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute, fifty-five... fifty...  forty-five... etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-five, forty-six, forty-seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that it all comes out in a near dead-heat, with Dragli yelling and popping in eggs. At the last second before  deadline, two whole eggs are shoved into Luke's mouth, an Dragline rams Luke's mouth shut for him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All in: that's it: chew, chew, chew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen, ten, nine, eight, seven...  six...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke looks around, then takes a mighty swallow, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One... zero!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke collapses with his head on the table, his arms flung out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't swallow the last...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs him by the hair and pulls his head back. Draglin pries his mouth open with his fingers. Luke is out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they all peer down into his throat. Dragline grins, lo around at Society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the egg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps Luke on the cheek affectionately, closes his mou and lets his head fall back on the table with a loud thum his arms again sprawled out in the piles of egg shells. A dance of victory for Dragline... he collects all over the place. Dynamite, shaking his head, quietly knights the ne champion hog-gut by laying his big spoon on the table nex to Luke's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car ROARS by, leaving a hint of laughter and music in t air and a cloud of dust. The men are working rhythmically Godfrey watching.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTH STEVE GAMBLER
dialogues.text: They have been observing Godfrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man looks like a goddamn bus driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yoyoing) He gets too close to me and I'll cut  his belly open.

dialogues.speaker: KOKO
dialogues.text: He sees snake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snake in the grass! Boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs. Men flail at the snake in the grass with their y and CAMERA MOVES WITH Snake though we can't see it and we follow its progress only by the men jumping, hitting at i yelling.

dialogues.speaker: GODFREY
dialogues.text: He rams his cane into the soft sand and Rabbit reaches in the truck cab and hands him his rifle. Godfrey slams the  bolt in.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MEN
dialogues.text: They jump and yell and chase the snake until they reach L who stoops, grabs cooly and comes up with the snake, hold it by the tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pickin' it up here, Boss!

dialogues.speaker: GODFREY
dialogues.text: His EYES HUGE IN THE SCREEN: Luke seen there IN DUPLICATE standing tall in the sun, grinning, the rattler wriggling and thrashing in his grasp. Godfrey's face holds for a lo beat then the rifle is brought up so that we can now see  Luke CLEAR IN ONE LENS and the other he is lined up in th rifle sight pointing directly INTO THE LENS -- or just CA LEFT. There is a SHOT and the rifle is lowered enough so can see Luke IN DUPLICATE again.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: looking at Godfrey, grinning, but a little tougher now. T snake has no head. He walks down a little and throws the  body of the snake on the road at Godfrey's feet. It bring him close to where Godfrey's cane still stands in the san Godfrey kicks at the snake. He turns... Luke pulls the ca out of the sand and holds it out to Godfrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget your walking stick,  Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godfrey turns to face him and stares at him. Luke just ho the stick out to him. Godfrey slowly takes the bolt out o the rifle, looks down the barrel, blows the smoke out, pu the bolt in his pocket and hands the gun back to Rabbit b finally reaching out and taking the stick from Luke. He t and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shore can shoot, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godfrey's shoulders almost jerk as though at every word h were being hit with invisible bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, why you actin' so strange?  What you wanna do somethin' like  that for? You gone too far when you  mess with the Man With No Eyes. You  gonna be outa here in a little bit --  whyn't you jus' take it a little  easy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke has been staring up at the darkening sky which is gr more ominous with clashing clouds and rolling thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, it looks like the Big Boss is  getting ready to let us have it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It begins to rain, large spattering drops, quickly turnin into a downpour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, you kin git in that truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang rushes back into the shelter, all except Luke an Dragline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Him go. Bam! Bam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock it off, Luke! You cain't talk  about Him that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline begins to move off toward the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still believe in the Big Bearded  Boss, Drag? You think he's up there  watching us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins at Dragline and then, after a beat, raises his b axe straight up to the sky, grinning at Dragline.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: He is frightened as he backs off toward the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in here! Ain't you scared --  ain't you scared of dyin'?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: The rain is torrential. He has to shout to be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dyin'? He can take back this nice  pretty life any time He wants. (looks up) You welcome to it, Old Timer. Come  on! Make me know you're up there!  Kill me or love me, one or the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds his bush axe again, laughing, soaking wet.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE BACK OF TRUCK
dialogues.text: The men jammed into the frame of the body, a frieze of sh faces staring out at him through the rain. There is a bli flash of lightning and a THUNDEROUS ROAR. They wince but  don't turn away.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He smiles and lowers the bush axe, walking toward the tru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standin' out here in the rain! All  alone! Talkin' to myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles a little shamefaced, rueful, sad smile and clim into the truck and the men draw back from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godfrey seen dimly through the rain-misted windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the free hour. But instead of the poker game, Dragl Luke and Koko sit at the table dealing with their line of debtors from the egg-eating. Koko acts as secretary, chan the amounts as the men pay off or borrow more. As Blind D receives his money and leaves:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Koko) Blind Dick is payin' us off three  and borrowin' back five. Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Borrowin' or payin' back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Borrowin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Cool Hand here is the soft  heart in our Loan Department. Next!

dialogues.speaker: ON CARR AT THE WICKER, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: He has just been handed a telegram by the Wicker Man. He  reads it impassive as always, while in b.g., the business continues and we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe I still owe you thirty. I  don't suppose you'd take a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke) My Navy disability didn't come yet.  You know how it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr finishes reading and we FOLLOW HIM as he walks to th table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure do... that's why we didn't bet  with the Navy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's mah darlin' Luke. Grins  like a baby and bites like a 'gator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr sets the telegram on the table next to Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke picks up the telegram and reads. Then he sets it dow stands and goes to his bunk. Dragline looks after him, ta up the telegram and hands it up to Society Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after reading) His mother's dead.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTH STEVE
dialogues.text: As he sees Luke go to his bunk, he picks up his sex book moves down to the other end of the barracks. Alibi does t same with the cigarette papers and tobacco he has been  rolling.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: sitting on his bunk, bare feet tucked up beneath his draw up legs, softly picking out a slow hymn melody on his ban Tears slowly stream down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: as Luke continues playing softly. He walks down to the ot end of the barracks, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the other men are congregated at the other end, gi Luke what privacy they can. There is no conversation, onl the slow, plaintive plucking of the banjo.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE CLOSE
dialogues.text: playing, the tears coursing.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: in his bunk now, staring wet-eyed up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty, awright, Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the men pour out they see that the light on the box is burning, a nightshirt is hung on the fence. Their usual h up pace is slowed to a nervous, apprehensive gait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, git lined up here.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN'S PORCH
dialogues.text: He has been watching, rocking. As the men line up, he get up and goes down the steps toward the yard. CAPTAIN'S P.O.V. pushing the gate open, moving in front of Boss Paul, faci the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, fall out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke steps forward, pulls off his shirt and jacket. He st behind the latticework screen to take off his pants as th Captain speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emotionless) When a man's mother dies and he gits  to thinkin' about her funeral and  payin' respects, before he knows it  his mind ain't right and he's got  rabbit in his blood and runs. We're  keepin' you off the road fer awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has said all he has to say. He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are watching him slip on the nightshirt. Boss Kean o the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke) Ah'm jus' doin' mah job, Luke. You  gotta appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss, when you do somethin' to me  you better do it because you got to  or want to... but not because it's  your damn job.

dialogues.speaker: KEAN
dialogues.text: His eyes narrow. The box door slams. Greyness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, let's move it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And o.s. the SOUNDS of the men counting through the gate the truck engines coughing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD DAWN, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: The bull gang truck pulling out. In b.g. the barracks and the light over the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bull gang truck stopping. The back is opened and the jump out, line up and begin counting off through the gate In b.g. as they count is Luke's voice singing.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: He smiles... oh that Luke!

dialogues.speaker: BOSS GODFREY
dialogues.text: listening to the mocking voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the next morning. The tire iron SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First bell! First bell! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figures of Boss Paul and Boss Seven go to the box. Se carries Luke's food. INT. BOX PAUL'S P.O.V. as it is opened. The dimness of the overhead bulb illumin Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the door, Boss. You're lettin'  in a draft.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: His face corrodes in fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git on your feet! Ah'm gonna teach  you some respect right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furiously he tries to cane Luke with his walking stick. B the cramped quarters restrict him. The cane clangs wildly against the sides of the box as Luke crouches in a corner covering his head.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: protecting, as Boss Paul retreats. The box door slams!  Greyness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the bull gang counts in after the day's work. The ligh on the box still burns. No sound from Luke.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: He looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tire rim SOUNDS and the men scurry for their bunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last bell! Last bell! (the pacing of his  steps) Forty-nine, Boss. And one in the  box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-nine and one in the box. Right,  Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Paul, carrying a shotgun, and Boss Seven are opening the box. In b.g. the tire rim SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First bell! First bell! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the uproar of the men getting out of their bunks, hur to dress and line up by the chute. INT. BOX CLOSE SHOT LUKE'S P.O.V. as the door opens and the double muzzle of Boss Paul's sh gun stares. BOSS PAUL'S P.O.V. Luke is standing at the rear of the box, his arms crossed over his chest, his eyes slightly wild, his face dirty an stubbled. In b.g. the SOUND of Rudolph, the pet bloodhoun puppy, yipping. LUKE'S P.O.V. Paul's gun draws back. Boss Seven hands Paul a heavy bisc grinning. Rudolph is sniffing, nipping at Paul's trousers smelling the biscuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look hongry, Luke. (tosses biscuit in  his hand) Reckon this would taste mighty good,  but Rudolph looks pretty hongry,  too. Why don't we split it with the  pooch, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks the biscuit and dangles half over Rudolph who n and barks for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeding Rudolph) Tha's a good boy. (to Luke) Well, here's your piece, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: ON LUKE
dialogues.text: He speaks in a low, uneven voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might as well give it all to him,  Boss. I just ain't much hungry.

dialogues.speaker: ON BOSS PAUL
dialogues.text: Livid with rage, he slams the door! Greyness.

dialogues.speaker: LAUNDRY FLYING OVER FENCE
dialogues.text: (AFTERNOON)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as LAUNDRY BOY tries to catch the flying sheets, pants an shirts being tossed by the men. Behind him we SEE the  steaming, pumping cleaning machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laundry boy and machines in b.g. as Boss Kean and Boss Se go to the box. Boss Seven carries Luke's shoes and a fres cleaned set of state issues. The men turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the door opens. Luke looks up. Kean's face stares down not unkind. Luke moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Luke emerges, Kean behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) She's in the ground now, Luke. Best  forget about it. You got a day ana  half lay-in... and tomorrow's a  holiday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fourth of July. All hell is breaking loose. Four radi going, chain men jitterbugging, one of the men has a mout harmonica, another plucks Luke's banjo. A lemonade barrel in a corner and men dip into it with coke bottles; others are banging together bottles as instruments, playing comb etc.

dialogues.speaker: ALIBI AND DYNAMITE
dialogues.text: just filling their bottles with lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toasting) Happy Fourth of July.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, if anyone had told me where I  was going to be spending Independence  Day... (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: ON MUSIC MAKERS, OTHERS
dialogues.text: Most of them are concentrated in front of Luke's bunk, si and screaming, trying to make as much noise as possible.  Tattoo is reading a new sex book aloud while Dynamite,  Loudmouth Steve, others listen intently, some avid, some  confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Wanda trembled, faced by this awesome  decision. It was the moment of choice.  Could she take the plunge and wantonly  hurl herself into pagan abandon? Or  would she remain ever fettered by  the bonds of her puritanical  upbringing? Could she take this chance  to experience the sensual thrill of  total release and gratification? Or  would she turn her back and retreat  into frigid denial? Desire and fear,  temptation and terror, yearning and  horror, warred within her beautiful  young body...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke is not to be seen among the music-makers and revelle Moving through the crowd, the CAMERA FINDS Luke on his ha and knees, sawing at the floorboard with a piece of hacks

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: as the tire iron SOUNDS and SOUNDS again to be heard over the din.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First bell! Let's git to bed. You  done had your fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The singers and music-makers around Luke finish their son reaching a high, piercing, noisy crescendo. At the same t Dragline has been reading another sex book to Stupid Blon Blind Dick and Chief who are trying to act out the  description, tying themselves into an intricate anatomica knot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) She moved her head another inch while  he reached up and put his left hand  on Carol's cheek as Carol pressed  her lips to... Oh Lord, I can't read  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wriggles, panting with eye-popping pleasure, attractin Carr's attention. Stupid Blondie, Rabbit and Chief are st trying to untie themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr. Lookit this. Oh I don't believe  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got there, Drag? You bought  yourself another of them dirty books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intrigued, Carr sits down on Dragline's bunk and follows  Dragline's finger pointing out the lascivious parts. He i quickly absorbed.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: He looks over toward Luke who can be seen between the leg of the surrounding men, poised, waiting to drop down into the hole. Dragline winks.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He winks back, grins and disappears through the hole in t floor.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE AND CARR
dialogues.text: The tutor and the student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a real hot one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr reads intently.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE HOLE BENEATH LUKE'S BUNK
dialogues.text: gaping, empty, inviting.

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS REACTIONS OF MEN
dialogues.text: A. KOKO - suppressing a giggle. B. SOCIETY RED - considering it, cowardly. C. ALIBI - tense, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO
dialogues.text: He has been considering it, weighing his chances, his eye darting from the hole to Carr, back again. Now he scurrie to the hole, drops inside.

dialogues.speaker: CARR, DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: as the tire iron SOUNDS. Carr gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, last bell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are in their bunks, Carr begins to make his count As he comes to Tatto's bunk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEY, CARR! WHAT'S THAT OUTSIDE?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr rushes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's on the fence, boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Tattoo, half-way up the fence, startled by the clam as the Wicker Man whales the GONG. He falls back down, st up again, dogs BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as guards come running from the Captain's house, the dogs HOWLING.

dialogues.speaker: ON TATTOO
dialogues.text: frantically trying to get up the fence, falling down, sta to run, seeing the guards approaching with guns and canes turning to the other direction: more guards. Caught like rat, eyes wild with fear, he makes terrified motions to g in one direction, then the other but is rooted by fear an indecision as the guards move in. He SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: WICKER AND DOOR
dialogues.text: which is unlocked. Dogboy is dressed, combing his hair, s importantly putting on his gloves while the men lie in th bunks, staring contemptuously. Boss Paul, Godfrey and oth stare with shotguns leveled from the wicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr has been tearing a sheet off Luke's bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson. He cut a hole in the floor,  Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the sheet to Dogboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't even got the sense to run  from the road like everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue'll git him, Boss. We'll git  that bastid, Cool Hand Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Paul is unlocking the pen. Dogboy stands by the scre letting the yapping, frothing hounds sniff at the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan' back, Dogboy. Git the leash  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he opens the pen, the hounds rush out. Dogboy grabs on Boss Paul grabs another but Big Blue, the lead hound, has the scent and he bolts, howling and tearing off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue! Come back here! Come back, I  said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, smiling, running like hell through the murky water. b.g. Blue's baying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue in pursuit, sniffing, dashing, on the trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogboy with the other dogs being pulled through the muddy murky, thickly-foliaged swamp. Behind him, wading unhappi through knee-deep water are Bosses Paul, Higgins and Shor

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ABANDONED RAILROAD STATION NIGHT, (LATER)
dialogues.text: Boss Paul is on the phone to the Captain, Bosses Higgins Shorty sit disconsolate, dirty, wet, exhausted. Only Dogb is still eager, two hounds by his feet, listening in the  distance to the howl of Blue baying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to Blue sing. She's on to  him. She says: got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hail, that dog is jus' runnin' in  circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning from phone) Captain says to wait 'til the Patrol  gits here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listening to Blue) She's on to him. You shoulda waited  fer me to git her out -- loose like  she is, he kin run her crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't my fault you don't know how  to handle your dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How my suppose to handle a dog someone  jus' let loose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beat. This ain't mah job, nohow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Highway Patrol car pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the Patrol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling up dogs) She's got him! You hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Higgins and Shorty shake their heads wearily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dogboy) Okay, let's get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke steps under and through the pipeline supports and  vanishes. In b.g. Blue's plaintive HOWLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogboy moves ACROSS the SCENE with his pack of dogs, havi trouble following through the supports. The Officer behin him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: plodding along, exhausted, yanking at the dogs as they pu in different directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rudolph, Austin, you no  good buncha chicken-eaters, we're  lookin' for a man. We got us a job  to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke carefully slips through the barbs, runs a few yards, slips back through again, runs a few yards, returns to th other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogboy with his pack and the Officer. In b.g. Blue is HOW the dogs are BAYING frantically. It is with trouble that  Dogboy and the Officer get through the fence, pulled by t eager dogs. Then they must cross it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dogs are crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps criss-crossin'. He's  smarter'n a dog. But he ain't got us  boxed yet... Blue'll get him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAILROAD BRIDGE DAY
dialogues.text: A trestle built of creosoted timber. The dogs reach it, b up into a milling, confused mass. Dogboy wrestles them ou of the trestle. In b.g. as always, Blue's plaintive BAYIN

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGE
dialogues.text: as Dogboy fights the dogs to get them across.

dialogues.speaker: FAR SIDE OF BRIDGE
dialogues.text: as Dogboy hauls at the dogs who are pulling in different  directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: exhausted, disappointed, looking around, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs are confused, seem to mill around aimlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost in tears) Dammit. (calling) Blue! Blue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: running through the thick overhead cover. It is like a ju PULLING UP SLOWLY to HELICOPTER SHOT, we SEE that the cov is only a small patch of foliage and on the other side is huge panorama of rolling, empty moor-like country in whic after a moment, Luke enters, a tiny figure, running free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are coming out of the mess hall, washing their sp about to line up for inspection. A Highway Patrol car pul up outside the gate; from the back seat comes the yipping dogs. Every head turns. The Captain moves from his rocker and starts down the porch. Boss Paul and Godfrey move tow the car.

dialogues.speaker: PATROL CAR, (LATE AFTERNOON)
dialogues.text: as the Officer (seen at the railroad station) gets out an opens the front door. He nudges a sleeping, grizzled figu who emerges. It is Dogboy. The back door is opened and Ru and the other small dogs leap out, cavorting, glad to be  home. Then the Officer and Dogboy go to the trunk. The Of opens it. Dogboy reaches in and carries out -- the body o Big Blue. Staggering with fatigue, tears in his eyes, Dog stumbles up to the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Cap'n. Look what he done to  Blue. He's dead, Cap'n. Dead! Run  hisself plumb to death. That crazy  sadis Cool Hand Luke run her 'til  her heart bust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-eight, Boss. One in the box  and one in the bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bull Gang is working at the bottom of a high embankme and the guards stand on the road high above their heads,  looking down, shotguns out now, alert. The men work away a rackety pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he turns at the SOUND of a distant motor approaching a the image of a car coming closer enlarges in his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up beside the guards and the door opens. Th Captain steps up to the road edge and looks down. He says something to Boss Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, hold it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men stop working, puzzled, looking up. Then from the a guard escorts Luke to the edge of the pavement. Luke gr down at the men sheepishly. His prison uniform is filthy torn, his hands are cuffed behind his back, his face is d and stubbled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are stunned, saddened.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, CAPTAIN, GUARDS
dialogues.text: Behind Luke are Godfrey, Paul, Bosses Six and Seven and t Captain. Kean and Shorty flank the gang. The guns are hel levelled at the men. One guard uncuffs Luke's hands; othe produce a sledge hammer, ballpeen hammer and a set of leg irons from the Captain's car. Two guards kneel before Luk and begin hammering on the irons. Silence except for the  HAMMERING AND CLINKING. Luke is silhouetted, a tall, stra figure on the low horizon. The Captain looks directly ahe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke) You gonna get used to wearing them  chains aftera while, Luke. But don't  you never stop listenin' to them  clinkin'. That's gonna remind you of  what I been sayin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they sure do make a lot of  cold, hard, noise, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain feeds his fury staring, then reaches out his  hand and Boss Paul lays the blackjack in it. As the chain guards finish and stand up, trembling with rage, the Capt takes a convulsive step forward and brings the sap down b Luke's ear. As Luke tumbles down the littered embankment  toward the men:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you never talk that way to me!  You hear? You hear? Never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His rage subsides and his voice becomes calm, reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the men) What we got here is a failure to  communicate. Some men you can't reach,  that is they just don't listen when  you talk reasonable so you get what  we had here last week, which is the  way he wants it, well he gets it,  and I don't like it any better than  you men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nodding curtly, the Captain gets back in his car. Someone throws a shovel down the embankment. It CLATTERS until it lands beside Luke. Dragline and the others are by his sid helping him to his feet. Above Godfrey stares down at the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, buddy. You be awright. You  give 'em a run for their money. Jus'  take it slow and easy, baby. You  gonna make it fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Luke tries to get his bearings, someone thrusts the sh into his hands and they get him going like a rusty piece machinery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, buddy. Show 'em you're  awright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke seems to nod and begins to work slowly. The others b away, glancing fearfully at the guards, go back to work,  quiet and sullen.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He is working with great difficulty, stiff, tired, aching

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, let's eat them beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke stumbles gratefully toward the chowline.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CHOWLINE
dialogues.text: Dogboy dishing it out to Luke. Dogboy is gleeful, gloatin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew they'd git you. With them  chains an a bonus of a coupla years,  you runnin' days is over forever.  Ah'd like to see you try to run agin.  You gettin' so you smell so bad, I  could track you myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a natural born son of a bitch  like you, that oughta be easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Luke settles down with his beans, the others find spot around him so he is the focus of the group. We SEE Tattoo chains, forlorn. Luke wolfs his food hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jus' take it slow, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unable to restrain  himself) What happened? How far did you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. Let him eat. Don't pay them  no mind, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently) I gotta know -- How... how'd they  get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (between mouthfuls) Topflight police work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You steal a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, found one in this supermarket,  keys in the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how far didya get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating) Fat mile'n a half. Hit this red light,  highway patrol pulls up alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didya fight it out with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. I jus' kept lookin' straight  ahead waiting for that light to  change. And he kept lookin' over,  wondering what somethin' that looked  like me was doin' drivin' a shiny  new car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he leans over and sees this  state issue... All there was to it.  Feller's probably a lieutenant by  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke continues to shovel in his beans. The men are clearl disappointed. Only Dragline understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now we jus' gonna lay low and  build time and afore you know it the  heat'll be off you and things be  back where they was. Right, sweet  buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke winks and slaps Dragline affectionately on the cheek During this last, Luke has been idly winding a piece of k string found on the ground beside him. As, idly, he shove it into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS KEAN LATER
dialogues.text: The gang has resumed working, Kean stands looking out at horizon, not talking directly to Luke, just leaning on hi gun, following Luke whenever he moves, his voice as calm secure as a priest in his study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah hears tell you don't believe in  no God, Luke. Ah was wonderin' how  come a nice lookin' feller like you  come to get put on the Hard Road.  But now ah reckons ah knows. Ah been  on the Road Gang for twenny-two year,  Luke, and in all that time I ain't  never killed no white man but I ain't  afeerd to cause a body has to do his  work. And I ain't never seen no man  that wasn't afeerd to die neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, Boss. Don't mean to  interrupt... but... caught short  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Kean is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slow, dangerous) Awright, Luke. Thas okay... You go  on up there in them trees. Man's  gotta have some privacy sometime.  But you grab a bush and keep shakin'  it, hear? Jes' so we know you're  there. Jes' keep shakin' that bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to trot off, awkward in his chains. Kean looks Godfrey who snaps his fingers to Dogboy, a gesture that m rifle. Dogboy runs to the truck and brings back the rifle which Godfrey loads and arms with the bolt from his pocke

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Slowly walking off into the rough grass, his chains catch on brush and stumps. He disappears behind a large bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke's bush is in distance. He raises the gun to his shou and FIRES. REVERSE HIS P.O.V. The bush shakes, we can't see Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm shakin' it, Boss. I'm shakin'  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the dust kick up behind the stump and another SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still shakin' it, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: impassively: SHOOTS again, aiming. REVERSE HIS P.O.V. The bush goes on shaking. Then it stops.

dialogues.speaker: GODFREY
dialogues.text: Caught loading. He brings up the rifle fast, FIRES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang stops working, looks up stunned.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS KEAN AND GODFREY
dialogues.text: A long beat of shock -- they (and us) think Godfrey's hit him. Boss Kean trots hurriedly up to the bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Kean appears, looking down and off. CAMERA ADJUSTS s we see what he sees: a piece of kite string tied to the b and leading off into the brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and rushing back down toward Godfrey, others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone! Git the dogs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a rutted country road with farms on both sides. Luk appears, a filthy wide-eyed, stumbling, bearded beast in  filthy uniform and chains. PAN with him past sharecropper village of ramshackle huts, rusted junk. An OLD NEGRO WOM sees Luke and goes inside, closing the door. PAN with him a General Store where an OLD NEGRO MAN watching, quickly  retreats inside leaving only two small Negro boys (BEN an LAWRENCE) staring at Luke as he shambles toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at chains) Whattaya got them on for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you take your pants off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Well -- the best way is to take the  leg irons off first. (to Lawrence) But you ain't strong enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strong enough for whut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't heft an axe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's off, running toward a house. In the distance now, we hear the dogs baying, coming closer. Luke smiles at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben. (a beat) Had'n you better take them stripes  off your pants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling, Luke sits in the dirt and begins ripping off the stripes as Lawrence appears, dragging a huge double-bitte axe behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben) You wanna see somethin' funny? Go  get some chili powder, pepper, curry,  dried mustard and like that. A lot  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben rockets off and Luke turns to see Lawrence, strugglin mightily, attempting to bring the axe over his head and d on the chains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the axe, sets the chains up on a stump and begin to back heavily, BAYING OF DOGS growing louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, me, me. Let me do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawrence cries and stomps unhappily, clouding up dust as  Luke severs the chain from one shackle. Ben APPEARS with armload of spices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's them spices. (looks at Lawrence,  crying, stomping) What's wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke begins backing away, scuffing his feet in the dust,  pouring out the spices as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: stopping at Lawrence. The baying of the dogs is much clos now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember how them dogs do when  they get here so you can tell me  about it someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is gone.

dialogues.speaker: ON DOGS IN DISTANCE
dialogues.text: They are approaching quickly.

dialogues.speaker: ON VILLAGE
dialogues.text: Some of the people have reappeared, now go back inside.

dialogues.speaker: DOGS
dialogues.text: They fill the FRAME, milling around the empty street,  sneezing, howling, stirring up dust, pawing at their nose

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is peeping from a corner. His tears stop and he smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...cutting away at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it passes the Negro Church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thas the church. After he chopped  off those old chains and whilst he  was layin'd down the pepper --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard it was curry powder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was pepper and curry powder and  dry mustard. Now shut your face.  Whilst he was layin' down them spices,  Luke heard them choir practicin' in  there. So he just sauntered inside,  cool's kin be, and sung along with  them... my baby Luke... and he was  still singin' when the dogs come by,  singing and grinning and eatin' the  food the people had brung him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bull gang at the end of bean time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, let's git to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline and the others deposit their chow plates, pick u their yoyos and start to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't eating beans fer lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's eatin' steak and corn with butter  and green beans and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...fried clams, pizza, chocolate,  malted milkshakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yoyoing) ...and a Brown Bomber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yoyoing) Shut your mouth. He's out there doin'  it for all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Saturday afternoon. Carr is distributing mail and  packages, the men clustered around; others lying on bunks making wallets, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magazines for you, Dragline!

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE
dialogues.text: Dragline sits up from his bunk, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magazines? Who's sendin' me magazines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the package. Carr has tossed on his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From mah uncle? Ah never heard from  him in eight years and now he's  sendin' me magazines. He musta gone  crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has torn open the package, looks through the magazines which are movie fan books, lies back to flip the pages. I b.g. Carr is continuing the mail call. Suddenly Dragline' eyes widen, his mouth opens, but he catches himself and c it before he has revealed himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is taped to page in the magazine. It shows Luke in a s and tie, holding up four aces and a joker in one hand, ar around two buxom over-made strippers. On the table in fro of them is a giant bottle of champagne and glasses. Scraw across it is something in Luke's writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing Dragline's reaction, they have gathered around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looka that! Two of them. Oh my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dyin'. I'm dyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline suddenly realizes the danger and closes the book Carr and the Wicker Man don't catch on. The others reluct move away. Dragline casually hands the magazine to Societ Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) What's the writing say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening to the  picture, reading) Dear Boys. Playing it cool. Wish you  were here. Love, Cool Hand Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my. Oh my... Give it back here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red surrenders the magazine. Dragline opens it again and look of pure bliss settles over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme see it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (violently) Get away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over at Carr but Carr has moved away, is talking the Wicker Man, his back to the men. Koko, Loudmouth Stev Gambler and the others hurriedly cluster around Dragline. Their voices are eager intense whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit the brunette...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde's gotta better set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must be six feet tall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from his bunk) Domestic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonder how he got the dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably a salesman. You can  make pretty good money if you know  what your doing in selling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A salesman! Cool Hand Luke a salesman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably a gigolo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a con artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The head of the rackets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reverently) Oh lookit that brunette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mah baby! We're diggin' and dyin'  but our boy Luke is lovin' and flyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all gaze at the picture with loving, dreamy, painful rapture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blackass time, dull, sad, boring. Koko sits idly flicking cards from the poker deck, men staring into space. The ca sail by Society Red who is clipping his nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you tryin' to make me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They slowly subside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline, lemme look at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigned innocence) What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Drag. Get it out for a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just a kid. Whatta you know  about it? You don't wanna see that  dirty picture. Luke and those broads  an' all that booze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Drag. Lemme take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'd go to your coconut head. You'd  start getting ideas. Maybe even pass  right out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline! Be a buddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you figure it's worth, a  peek at this here picture? A quick  look, I'm not talkin' about no  memorizin' job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold drink? You mean one cold drink?  To feast yore starvin' fishy l'il  eyes on The Picture? A true vision  of Paradise itself? With two of the  angels right there in plain sight a- friskin' round with mah boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold drink? Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --- okay. It's a deal. One cold  drink, if'n you please. In advance.  One chilly bottle right here in mah  hot l'il hand... That goes for the  rest of you mullet-heads, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Activity as the men dig out coins to purchase drinks. Dra pulls out the magazine and the men all gather round, gazi into it as though it were a crystal ball. Suddenly the wi door slams open and as the men look up... THEIR P.O.V. Luke is dumped to the floor, face down, unconscious, by B Paul, Boss Kean, others. The Captain is standing there ov him. Luke wears a new prison uniform and two sets of chai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke) You run one time, you got yourself a  set of chains. You run twice, you  got two sets. You ain't gonna need  no third set because you're gonna  get your mind right... And I mean  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the men who are stunned by the juxtaposition their hero in The Picture and the reality of the unconsci figure before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a good look at your Cool Hand  Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his foot he prods Luke over onto his back.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: As he rolls over we can see he has been badly beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Captain turns and walks out past the guards who fo and the wicket chute CLANGS shut, Dragline, Koko and othe move forward and gently lift Luke onto the poker table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh mah poor baby. They done you real  good... I don't know if you gonna  have them gals chasin' after you for  a while...

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: lying, eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They half killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should have a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you never learn nuthin'? They  ain't gonna let no doctor see what  they dont to him...

dialogues.speaker: DRAGLINE, OTHERS
dialogues.text: Dragline looks up at Carr who stands hovering above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr, kin we use your razor to clean  up where they cut his head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr moves off to his canteen area.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: as Blind Dick, Gambler, others move in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you feelin', buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody get him something to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gently he tucks two aspirin tablets into Luke's mouth, ho a cup of water to Luke's mouth. Luke's eyes slowly open, drinks the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna be awright.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: as Carr moves in with a razor, bandage, etc. The men clea to give him room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke?... We got the picture! See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: His eyes squint open, close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of beauties. Best I ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really know how to pick 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us about 'em. What were they  like?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: as his lips open. He speaks slowly, painfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picture's a phoney... Cost me a week's  pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phoney? Whatta you mean, a phoney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw the broads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Did you have them both at once  or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a phoney. Made it up just for  you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on. We saw it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really had it made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin. I had nothin, made nothin.  Couple towns, couple bosses. Laughed  out loud one day and got turned in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about to cry) But -- but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all there was. Listen. Open  your eyes. Stop beatin' it. And stop  feedin' off me. Now get out of the  way. Give me some air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, the men shrink back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't himself. He's all beat up.  Cain't you see that? He don't know  what he sayin'.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD DAY
dialogues.text: Luke is working with great difficulty, pained, weary unde the double set of chains. Bosses Paul and Kean stand righ over him, watching every move.

dialogues.speaker: GODFREY
dialogues.text: standing far behind, his mirrored eyes on Luke.

dialogues.speaker: ON LUKE
dialogues.text: moving, he stumbles on the chains, gets hit by Paul's can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You was eyeballin', Luke. You can't  gitcha mind on them weeds if yer  eyeballin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) Boss, you don't need reasons to hit  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets the cane again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna learn you not to back sass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Luke is slammed into it and the door is closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poker game is in progress: Dragline, Koko, Blind Dick Gambler, Tattoo with Tramp behind him. Society Red stands the window, looking out as he brushes his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll never make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know when to give in.  They'll kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give in? That's our Luke out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ole box collapse and fall apart  before Luke calls quits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Luke's got more guts than brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see no sign of guts in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No chains either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heating up) You ain't man enough to wear them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're dog enough. Maybe they'll  let you sleep outside the box near  your master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big deal paper hanger! Hell, anyone  who can write can pass fifty-sixty  dollar checks. Like breakin' open a  piggy bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been having bad luck with  masters, haven't you? Your last one  left you when the cops came... and  now Luke. You should complain to the  S.P.C.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushing him) You phony creep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragline steps in to separate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, that's enough. You wanna  end up in the box, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tire rim sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First bell! First bell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men file in from work, sullen and quiet, Dogboy servi but without his usual chatter. Higgins leans back, unusua alert.

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: Suddenly Luke appears, unshaven but cleaned up and in his uniform. The men make room as he moves to his accustomed  place at the head of the line, before Dynamite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's our champeen hog gut. Ain't  et for four days, gonna need a little  extra... Well we got plenty for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's heaping food onto Luke's plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now you know the rules... gotta eat  everything on the plate or go back  in the box, right, Boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Higgins nods, Dogboy continues to pile it on. When Luke t to move on, Dogboy reaches out and grabs the plate with h free hand and continues to ladle it out. Behind Dogboy, J the cook, looks sympathetic to Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dogboy) We ain't got but one pot of stew,  you know. He ain't the only one  eatin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (piling it on) Man use to Free World food gotta big  appetite... so here's some more  potatoes and here's some ice cream  and some cake with choclat fudge  sauce... there you go, stretch that  hog-belly right out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
